title: Boeing Stock Is Still a Wall Street Favorite — Assuming the MAX Flies Again
text:
Text size

Many aviation stakeholders don’t seem happy with Boeing recently. Pilots aren’t happy with design choices made about 737 MAX flight controls and Congress has summoned CEO Dennis Muilenburg to testify this month.

Wall Street, on the other hand, still recommends Boeing shares. Analysts, more comfortable assessing income statements than aerospace designs, seem content to wait and react to MAX news as it trickles out.

More than 60% of analysts covering the stock rate shares Buy, better than the 55% average Buy-rating ratio for stocks in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. If the MAX never flew again—something no one on Wall Street expects—opinions would surely change. But with an event such as this, investors should realize Wall Street is in the same boat as everyone else—waiting for a complex regulatory drama to play out.

Jefferies analyst Sheila Kahyaoglu, for instance, updated her Boeing numbers in a Tuesday research report. She still assumes the MAX resumes flying in the fourth quarter, based on the company’s timeline. As a result, Kahyaogul rates shares Buy with a $430 price target, about 13% higher than recent levels.

Editor's Choice

“Near term, we forecast free cash flow per share of about $6 in 2019, climbing to $31 in 2020 as 737 MAX inventory unwinds and the company re-establishes productivity capture,” Kahyaoglu said in a Tuesday research report. (“Productivity capture” is another way of saying cost cutting.)

Based on the MAX returning, she doesn’t see the long-term earnings power of the aerospace giant disrupted. “Free cash flow outlook appears to sustain a rate of greater than $30 per share from 2020 to 2022.”

Free cash flow should approximate earnings and is preferred by some analysts when valuating companies, especially companies like Boeing that have large noncash charges related to aircraft design and block accounting assumptions—quirks of the aerospace industry. Boeing trade for about 12 times Kahyaoglu’s long-term free cash flow estimates, a level Kahyaoglu believes is attractive.

The back story. Boeing shares are down about 10% since the second crash of the 737 MAX, involving an Ethiopian Airlines flight. The two fatal crashes, which claimed the lives of 356 people, led to the world-wide grounding of the jet in mid-March.

Boeing believes it can return the plane to service by year-end after making changes to flight-control software, sensors and, potentially, providing more training for pilots.

What’s new. Kahyaoglu trimmed her estimates for sales and earnings in 2019, 2021 and 2022. She expects the company to report just $83.6 billion in sales and $3.80 a share in earnings for 2019. But she thinks sales will jump to $122.1 and $117.9 billion in 2020 and 2021, respectively. Earnings jump to $22.53 and $23.87 per share in her model for 2020 and 2021, respectively.

Looking ahead. Of course, the estimates in 2020 and 2021 are dependent on a safe return of the MAX. Wall Street won’t predict what happens to the plane. It will just react to the news, like every other stakeholder.

October is shaping up to be a big month for Boeing, with third-quarter earnings due, MAX updates hoped for and Congressional testimony for the CEO.

The stock was trading near the flat line at $380.54 Tuesday morning, The S&P 500 was down 0.3%.

Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com
description: Many stakeholders, including pilots and Congress, don’t seem happy with Boeing. Wall Street, however, recommends Boeing stock despite uncertainties over the grounded 737 MAX jet.
